ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PEDESTRIAN CROSSING AT
7TH MILE TAMPINES ROAD


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Poh Ber Liak -

    1. To ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether the Government intends to establish a pedestrian crossing at 7th mile Tampines Road, near the market and when.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Poh Ber Liak.

    There was no response.

Column: 341

PENG GHEE HIGH SCHOOL
(Government Assistance)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Poh Ber Liak :-

    2. To ask the Minister for Education whether the Government intends to give any assistance to Peng Ghee High School for development, and if he will give details.

    Mr Speaker: Question No. 2, Mr Poh Ber Liak.

    There was no response.

Column: 342

TANJONG RHU ESTATE MARKET


    3. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Health whether the Government has any plan to build a medium-sized market to replace the present covered pitches at the Tanjong Rhu Estate to serve the residents in the area.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Minister to reply.

    For the present, the Ministry of Health does not plan to build a medium-sized market in Tanjong Rhu Housing Estate as there is no available land for such a purpose. Arrangements were made previously with the Housing and Development Board to provide the present covered pitches for hawkers at a cost of $30,550 in 1963. It is too early yet to decide whether these covered pitches should be demolished and replaced by a small but not a medium-sized market, if any is to be built.

Column: 342

KALLANG AND TANJONG RHU ESTATES
(Electricity and water for pitches)


    4. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Health whether the Government will provide electricity and water supplies in the covered pitches in the Kallang and the Tanjong Rhu Estates, particularly for the night pitch-holders.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Minister to reply.

    It is not intended to provide electricity for covered hawker pitches in Kallang/Tanjong Rhu Estates as this would create an undesirable precedent in that no other hawker pitches have been provided with electricity.

    As for water supply, standpipes are already provided in these localities and they appear adequate at present.

    The position of these pitches, whether day or night, requires review as

Column: 343

these have developed beyond the original scope envisaged by the Ministry of Health.

Column: 343

MALAYSIAN MIRROR
(Particulars)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Ong Lian Teng :-

    5. To ask the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (a) the total number of employees involved in the publication of the Malaysian Mirror; (b) the amount of money spent on each issue; and (c) the Head and subhead of the 1965 Estimates which provides for the expenditure.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ong Lian Teng.

    There being no response -

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been directed by my Minister to state that a written answer to this question will be handed to the Clerk later for circulation to Members.

NANYANG UNIVERSITY
CO-OPERATIVE STORE
(Reasons for dissolution)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chia Thye Poh :-

    6. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development the reason for dissolving the Nanyang University Co-operative Store.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chia Thye Poh.

    There was no response.

Column: 343

ANCHORAGE FACILITIES AT UPPER SERANGOON ROAD


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether and when the Government will improve the anchorage facilities for fishing boats near the jetty at the end of Upper Serangoon Road.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development):

Column: 344

Mr Speaker, Sir, I am directed to answer on behalf of my Minister.

    An area of about 6,006 square yards near the jetty at the end of Upper Serangoon Road has been erected in order to improve the anchorage facilities for fishing boats and others using the jetty at a cost of $30,000. The work was completed on 15th October, 1965.

Column: 344

LEGALISATION OF TRAWLING
(Legislation)


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether and when the Government will introduce legislation to legalise trawling.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, it is the intention of the Government to draw up a new Fisheries Ordinance in order to encourage deep-sea and off-shore fishing, including trawling. The new legislation will be presented to the Assembly as soon as it is ready, and will contain provisions to permit trawling to be carried out without causing detrimental effects to our in-shore fishermen. In the meantime, those persons who wish to engage in deep-sea and off-shore fishing, including trawling, can consult officers of the Primary Production Department for advice and assistance.

SINGAPORE FAMILY PLANNING
AND POPULATION BOARD BILL

    Sir, I beg to introduce accordingly.

Column: 345

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Fifth Day)


2.40 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [14th December, 1965],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present Session of this Assembly.".'. - [The Prime Minister].

    Question again proposed.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the enforced emergence of Singapore as an independent and sovereign State is an event that has far-reaching consequences on the lives of the people of our country. The chain reaction started by this dramatic event has begun, and has become apparent in the allocation of expenditure in the first Budget of independent Singapore. Foreign affairs and defence are responsibilities which we can no longer avoid. These must be paid out of revenue. In the present state of affairs, it must mean that other fields of responsibilities cannot claim as large a share of the budget as had been the case in the past. Thus, the amount devoted to education next year has dropped from about one-third of the budget to 24 per cent. However, it must be noted that there has been a drop only in proportional terms of the whole budget. The actual amount allocated for education in absolute terms has increased, being $129 million or an increase of $16 million more than this year. In other words, education is still amply provided for, and will continue to make

Column: 346

progress. This is because the Government fully realizes that investment in education is crucial to economic and social progress, and that "no single factor is more likely to bring about a more fair and just society than equal opportunities for education for all."

    Before I outline the Government's education programmes for the future, let me briefly summarize our past achievements. By the end of this year, the present Government will have spent nearly $654 million on education since 1959. In return for this big outlay of public funds, we have built up an education system that has become the envy of many less fortunate countries.

    We have achieved universal free primary education without making it compulsory. There are enough school places to admit every child aged six plus, not only now but for many more years to come. Every child of school-going age is assured of a place in a school using the medium of instruction of his parent's choice. Once admitted, he is assured of ten years of primary and secondary education, finishing at the minimum age of 16 with at least a Secondary Vocational School Certificate. Of those who obtain the School Certificate, no less than 25 per cent are admitted to Pre-University classes to prepare for the Higher School Certificate and entry to the universities and the Polytechnic.

    Our school enrolment has shown spectacular increases. In the primary schools, the enrolment in Government and Government-aided schools has increased from 261,000 in 1959 to 360,000 in 1965, or an increase of about 38 per cent. Secondary enrolment has increased in an even more spectacular manner, having risen from 44,000 in 1959 to 113,000 in 1965, that is, an increase of 157 per cent. We should note with satisfaction that our total primary and secondary enrolment of 473,000 represents about 25 per cent of our entire population.

    This expansion in enrolment has been made possible by heavy capital outlays on the construction of schools. In this year alone, 15 new schools and four

Column: 347

major extensions to existing schools have been completed. All in all, the Government has built 72 new schools of all types, with 1,700 classrooms - excluding special rooms like the teachers' common room, the school hail, etc. - affording more than 125,000 places. These schools have been constructed at an average rate of one school per month.

    In order to ensure that no child in Singapore shall remain illiterate on account of financial difficulties, free primary education has been introduced for children born in Singapore or whose parents are Singapore citizens. In addition, there is provision for 15 per cent of the secondary enrolment to be free. About 17,000 pupils have been granted free secondary education under this provision on account of their financial background. Malays who are Singapore citizens enjoyed special assistance in education. Malay children have been guaranteed free education from primary schools to the University. All in all, about 35,000 Malay pupils are enjoying free education at all levels. Annually, large sums of money have been allocated for scholarships and bursaries. In this year, the Government has spent $1.6 million on scholarships and bursaries, and this amount has enabled 40,266 poor students to study in the secondary schools, universities and the Polytechnic. In addition, the Government has also spent $259,000 in the provision of free text-books.

    In the past five years, the Government has fulfilled its objectives with regard to primary education. From now onwards, the emphasis on education will be:-

    (i) the improvement of the quality of education at all levels;

    (ii) the expansion of educational facilities in the secondary and tertiary levels;

    (iii) diversification of educational development which is essential for the development of an industrial society; and

    (iv) the further development of education for national unity and tolerance in a multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-cultural society.

Column: 348



    Future building programmes will reflect the shift in the emphasis on priorities in education. Less primary schools will be built. It is expected that by the end of 1966, six primary schools and three major extensions to existing primary schools will be completed. In addition, four dilapidated and sub-standard-sized Malay schools - the Telok Kurau East School, the Telok Kurau Malay Boys' School, the Siglap Malay School and the Pulau Bukom Kechil Malay School - will be reconstructed and completed into standard-sized modern primary schools. Work will also begin on two new primary schools under the 1966 school building programmes in Toa Payoh and MacPherson South Housing Estates.

    The construction of secondary schools will receive special attention next year. In the course of next year, 13 new secondary schools and nine major extensions to existing schools will be completed, thereby providing an additional 36,000 places for secondary students. Furthermore, work on eight new secondary schools under the 1966 building programme will commence early next year. The building programme next year will ensure that every child who is now in primary school and with the eligible qualification will be assured of a place in secondary school.

    Under the Second Development Plan, the Government will also build a number of secondary schools to be known as Junior Colleges specially for Pre-University students. This will make possible the optimum use of teaching staff and laboratory facilities and relieve the secondary schools of the pressure for accommodation up to the Secondary IV level. Construction of one of these Junior Colleges will commence early next year. The Junior Colleges will admit Pre-University students from all the language streams, thereby bringing integration one stage nearer.

    The need to diversify our education system to meet the demand of industrialisation was recognised as early as 1960. Today there are nine secondary technical schools and nine secondary vocational schools which can provide a maximum enrolment of 18,000 students

Column: 349

in each type. However, in 1965, only 4,600 students were in secondary technical schools and 8,600 in secondary vocational schools. In 1966 it is expected that the number of students in secondary technical schools will increase by 63 per cent to 7,500 and the number of students in secondary vocational schools will increase by 34 per cent to 11,500. The 1965 enrolment in secondary technical and vocational schools as compared with the total secondary enrolment of 113,000 is only 11 per cent.

    To overcome the traditional prejudice against technical and vocational education in favour of academic education, a new feature has been introduced in our educational system, namely, the incorporation of workshop facilities into the secondary structure and consequent ending of the separation of schools into academic, technical and vocational units. In fact, all new secondary schools in future will have workshops.

    With the emergence of Singapore as an independent and sovereign State, the necessity to use education as an instrument to weld national unity and to build a nation out of its heterogeneous population has become urgent and unavoidable. The study of the National Language will be intensified at all levels without, however, affecting the medium of instruction in schools. For some years it has been compulsory for students in primary schools to learn a second language. It has now been decided that the study of a second language will be made compulsory in the Secondary school, beginning with Secondary I in 1966 and continuing on to Secondary IV in 1969, when every school candidate for the School Certificate Examination will be required to offer a second language. In this manner, all school leavers will at least be proficient in two languages. This policy, aiming at breaking down the language barrier in Singapore and enabling students of one language stream to appreciate the cultural and linguistic backgrounds of those in another language stream, will be extended to all our institutions of higher learning. In order that the additional teaching load

Column: 350

should not fall on the shoulders of our existing corps of teachers, extra provision of language teachers will be made. In the meantime, in-service courses for existing language teachers will be intensified so as to raise their efficiency and effectiveness.

    All the expansion in education could not have been made possible without co-ordinated efforts in increasing the number and quality of teachers. In 1960, full-time teacher-training was replaced by part-time in-service training in order to meet the unprecedented demand in primary education. With Primary I enrolment levelling-off at the rate of about 60,000 per annum for the last three years and a declining birth rate, the problem of increasing supply is now overcome and emphasis is now shifted to improving the quality of the training of teachers. A positive step will be taken towards qualitative improvement by a gradual reversion to full-time training. A second Teachers' Training College will be built under the Second Development Plan to take in fee-paying students on a full-time basis. With the establishment of this new College, it will be possible for the existing College to make a gradual reduction in the annual intake of part-time trainees and to start full-time training courses of its own. Eventually, both Colleges will have only full-time students for regular training, and more attention can be devoted to in-service courses for qualified teachers. The anticipated improvement in the quality of training will, in the years to come, be reflected in the quality of teaching throughout our schools.

    The curriculum and the intensity of training will, by and large, be similar to the present 3-year in-service training course but crammed into two years of full-time training. On graduation, they will become qualified teachers drawing the same salary as the 3-year in-service course teachers. The anxiety expressed by the Singapore Teachers' Union of a multiplicity of salary scales and more favoured treatment for these full-time students will not arise.

    Outside the regular school system, vocational training will be greatly expanded. Additional training facilities at the Singapore Vocational Institute, at

Column: 351

the cost of $1.65 million, are in the process of construction. When completed by the middle of 1966, the enrolment capacity will increase from the present 1,200 to 2,500. In addition, two new vocational institutes will be built under the Second Development Plan, one providing courses in the manual and applied arts, the other in engineering and building. When completed, the three institutes together will be able to take in about 6,500 students, including a proportion of those with the Secondary Vocational School Certificate, for training to become skilled craftsmen to meet the demand of our expanding industries.

    At a higher level of technical training, the Polytechnic has finalised arrangements for its graduates in Engineering, Building and Accountancy to he awarded degrees by the University of Singapore. The long-term plans of expansion envisaged moving the Polytechnic to a new site to develop into two separate units - a College providing training at Technician Diploma level and an Institute of Advanced Technology awarding Degrees of its own. With the establishment of these institutions, it is expected that Singapore will become a centre for technical and technological education in South-East Asia.

    In the next few years, more attention will be paid to integrating our higher institutions of learning into the national community so that they will the better serve society. Universities represent the apex of the educational system in a country. They have an essential and influential role in society, and the quality and character of the universities are bound to have important impacts on the social, economic, and political life of a country. The role and character of universities have varied from place to place and from time to time. Universities are simultaneously conservative and progressive institutions - conservative in the sense that they preserve the best in the culture of a society, and progressive in the sense that they introduce new ideas, new discoveries, and new inventions, usually for the betterment of society. As institutions of higher learning, universities throughout the world share certain common functions, but they differ also because they have to

Column: 352

cater for the different needs of the societies for which they purport to serve. It is obvious that universities in homogeneous societies with a well-developed sense of national identity have one important difference in role to play from universities in newly independent countries faced with the problems of building national identity out of a heterogeneous population. Problems, too, differ from one newly emergent heterogeneous country to another. Thus, most of the African countries are beset by the problem of building national identities out of diverse tribes, divided by a multiplicity of local dialects, loyalties and customs. In Singapore, where we are thrown by the circumstances of history and geography on the crossroads of trade and cultures, we are confronted by the immeasurably greater problem of fostering a national identity out of competing cultures - cultures which have an inherent vitality of their own. The hard facts of geography, history, and demography in South-East Asia have forced upon us the realisation that we cannot build our distinctive national identity on the basis of one race, one religion, and one language. Our brief experience in Malaysia has driven the lesson home.

    It is a matter of history that our universities were founded in different circumstances, without careful thought as to the burning problems imposed upon us by the complex character of our population. Mr Speaker, Sir, let me at this juncture quote certain extracts from the much publicised Nanyang University Curriculum Review Committee, a document more popularly known as the Wang Gung-Wu Report, and named after its Chairman, Professor Wang Gung-Wu, a local scholar, internationally known for his scholarship and linguistic proficiency in English, Chinese, and Malay. Parts of this report run as follows:

    `...there is an urgent need for people with a deep, rational and sympathetic understanding of the multi-racial basis of the country. The University should produce graduates able to guide the course of the country's development, and trained to administer the public services and manage the growth of commerce and industry, and specially equipped to meet the nation's need for rapid modernisation . . . It should be the aim of the University to produce graduates who

Column: 353

are at least bi-lingual, if not tri-lingual, in the languages relevant to the development of the country. The University cannot depend on outside teaching staff for an indefinite period of time. There must he every opportunity for the employment of young but highly qualified local graduates with a deep understanding of the conditions in the region. In this way, the University will play an increasingly valuable role in the service of our society.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the extracts I have just cited were written in the context of Malaysia and with reference to Nanyang University. But the views expressed are also valid for multi-racial Singapore and for the University of Singapore. In other words, both Nanyang University and the University of Singapore must reflect the character of the society which they serve. But the character and the dimensions of the problems differ. These arise from the fact that in one university, the question of university reforms has been wilfully turned by anti-national elements into a political issue on the preservation of Chinese education, while in the other the problem is one of adjusting the university to the realities of society in Singapore.

    Unlike Nanyang University, the University of Singapore is not faced with major re-organisation to bring it up to the requirements of modern university education. Internationally, it is recognised as an institution of higher learning with a reputation for scholarship because its standard of scholarship and teaching can measure up to international standards. Its international reputation is likely to increase with the implementation of its development programme. This expansion programme includes two new faculties, namely, a Faculty of Technology and a Faculty of Social Sciences. It also includes an Institute of Medical Specialties, a Science Tower, which is about to be completed, an animal farm to provide facilities for teaching and research, extensions to the Medical Faculty and new library facilities.

    In the case of the University of Singapore, there is no problem of raising standards. However, the University shares one common defect with Nanyang University. This concerns the sensitivity

Column: 354

of the universities to the character of their environment, and the political and social changes occurring therein. To begin with the University of Singapore, this institution has been somewhat slow in its responses. Nevertheless, it has begun to take a more realistic view of things. It has admitted for some years already students from the Chinese-medium stream and from Nanyang University. The indications are that its response to social changes and needs will he quickened, for there is a growing national consciousness in the university as more and more local staff are recruited into the university. In fact, about a year ago, the local staff, with a few notable exceptions, have organised themselves into an association dedicated to making the University of Singapore into a truly national institution, reflecting the needs and character of our society, without sacrificing international standards. They demanded a local Vice-Chancellor to head the University, and their demand was met. In the University of Singapore, steps have already been taken to revive the Malay Studies Department, and to strengthen the Chinese Studies Department in order to take in students from the Chinese stream. The Chinese Studies Department has already existed for about a decade, but it has failed to measure up to expectations. Obviously, a radical re-organisation of the Department is necessary. But more has still to he done to ensure that facilities for the study of languages will he made available to all students in the University. In a multi-racial society, the intelligentsia has not only to be multi-lingual in order to play an effective role in all walks of life, but bi-lingual and tri-lingual graduates have better chances in the competition for jobs and promotions. Even in the field of researches in the arts and social sciences, the bi-lingual or trilingual academic men have advantages over their mono-lingual rivals both in the scope and depth of their work. It is pertinent to observe that an increasing number of Western Universities have introduced the study of Asian languages and have required that their post-graduate students on Asian studies should have proficiency in these languages.

Column: 355



    The Government has set out to build Singapore into a model multi-racial, multi-lingual, and multi-cultural society in this region of South-East Asia. The contribution that the University can make towards helping the Government to achieve this end is immense. This is a challenging task which I think the University can fulfil, with a qualitative change in its orientation as more and more local staff with a national outlook come to control the University.

    The problem of reforms in Nanyang University is one of great magnitude, because anti-national elements have turned the efforts of re-organisation into a political issue on Chinese culture. Before I proceed, let me repeat in Parliament what the Government and the Nanyang University authorities have categorically stated so many times in the past and also recently, namely, that Chinese shall continue to be the main language medium of instruction even after re-organisation. The objective of re-organisation is to turn Nanyang University into an institution of higher learning consonant with the needs of modern university education in a heterogeneous society. This is a necessary step in order to fulfil the Government's educational policy of equal treatment for four languages - Malay, Chinese, Tamil, and English. Let me repeat the main features of the Government's policy on languages. Malay is the national language. The official languages are Malay, Chinese, Tamil, and English. In education, there is no discrimination against any of these languages. All four language streams of education have been accorded equal treatment. The Government has not only been giving full grant-in-aid to aided Chinese schools, but has also actively built schools for the Chinese language streams. There were only nine Government Chinese medium schools before June 1959. Today, there are 60 such schools, 28 of which are secondary schools and 32 are primary schools. This has made possible a major increase in the enrolment in Government Chinese medium schools. In 1959, the year in which the P.A.P. became the Government of Singapore, the enrolment in Government Chinese schools amounted to only 6,500. Today, the enrolment is

Column: 356

about 35,000, or an increase of nearly 540 per cent in enrolment within six years. All this increase and future increases mean that Nanyang University has to be re-organised so that those who have the necessary qualifications will be given a proper university education that is their due. Re-organisation means better qualified teachers for the Chinese-medium schools, with the result that the quality of Chinese education will be improved. It also means that Nanyang graduates will have the necessary qualifications to compete for other jobs. The best of them will be acceptable to do post-graduate work in universities abroad, with improved prospects for even better and more lucrative jobs, including employment in Nanyang University itself, when they return with post-graduate degrees.

    To summarise, Sir, the re-organisation of Nanyang University will benefit Chinese education at all levels as well as open up new opportunities for Nanyang graduates. Each and every individual graduate will gain by these changes; society will also gain by them. For there is a great deal of talent in the Chinese stream which has never had the opportunity for development because the education system has not been adequately staffed and, at university level, properly organised to give it full opportunity for development.

    The real question which the nation has to face is whether Nanyang University is to be allowed to be re-organised quietly and peacefully so that Chinese education will improve in quality at all levels within the context of a multi-racial nation, and Nanyang graduates will be in an equal position to compete for jobs and play a positive role in the life of a multi-cultural society. This is the real issue which all those who profess to love Chinese education must face. The issue is not the preservation or destruction of Chinese education. Unfortunately, the Barisan Sosialis and other pro-Communist organisations have confused the real issue and presented the re-organisation as an attempt to kill Chinese education and turn Nanyang University into an English University. Before I explain how the anti-national Communist elements

Column: 357

stirred up a campaign against re-organisation, let me briefly explain what they hoped to gain by it. Since 1961, the fortunes of the Communist Party and its front organisations, like the Barisan Sosialis, have gone from bad to worse. By fighting against merger and Malaysia, by getting involved with the Brunei revolt and the P.K.I., they have exposed themselves before the public. There is hardly any major issue left in Singapore for them to exploit except communalism. And it is not impossible to stir up Chinese feelings on questions of Chinese education, with unavoidable increase in communal feelings between the Chinese and other cultural groups. The re-organisation of Nanyang presents for the Communists and their supporters an Opportunity to stir up trouble. But the re-organisation of Nanyang University presents to them more than just an opportunity to stir up communal feelings; it is also a threat to their sources of supply of new recruits. With Nanyang University re-organised, and its graduates equipped for better jobs and a meaningful role in our society, their sources of supply will dry up. Furthermore, it will no longer be possible for them to make use of Chinese education as a political issue.

    For these reasons then, the re-organisation of Nanyang University has falsely been presented as a move to kill Chinese education. Unfortunately, a number of errors in the Chinese translation of the Report had been mischievously exploited to lend credence to their distortion that Nanyang University was to be converted into an English University. Under the pretext of the preservation of Chinese education, a group of pro-Communist students carried out a boycott of classes. The boycott is a familiar technique employed by the Communists when they stir up trouble in the Chinese educational stream. It involves violence, intimidation, and even arson, in the present case, the agitators resorted to physical violence against the Acting Vice-Chancellor and some members of the academic and non-academic staff.

    They intimidated and forcibly prevented students from attending classes. They committed vandalism by tampering with the locks of lecture rooms, and defacing all the University buildings except the library. They even tried to burn down a dormitory block. It will be noted that these criminal and destructive acts had been perpetrated against Nanyang University - itself a symbol of Chinese education and culture - by people who professed to preserve Chinese education and language. Their actions only served to prove their hypocrisy. In their campaign of vandalism and boycott of classes, the agitators were openly aided and abetted by the usual pro-Communist front organisations, the Barisan Sosialis, the Old Boys' Associations, and some trade unions. Unfortunately for them, the public was not convinced that the Government was anti-Chinese education and language. Without public support, the boycott collapsed ignominously.

It would appear that many Federation students find the relative liberalism and freedom in Singapore a convenient place for them to manifest their suppressed grievances and frustrations over the years in their home town where the cry was and still is "One race, one language, and one religion."

    Since re-organisation began in Nan-yang last July, the Government has donated a sum of $1 million for a new Library Building. Construction work on the Library has begun, and will be completed by about July 1966. Another $1 million has also been granted for the purchase of scientific equipment and library books. To enable the University to lower the fees for students who are Singapore citizens, Government subsidised the University to the extent of $81,000 in 1964 and $137,000 in 1965.     In the field of adult education, the Lembaga Gerakan Pelajaran Dewasa, now in its sixth year of existence, continues to provide a valuable service not only towards eradicating illiteracy and raising standards of education among adults, including the provision of facilities for learning a second or third language for those already proficient in one, the running of academic classes up to and including pre-university education, and conducting vocational classes, but also in widening the outlook of the citizens of Singapore by providing extra-mural courses to enable them to make more fruitful use of their leisure time. One, of course, is the Western standard textbook by

Column: 367

Clausewitz on The Art of War. But there is a much more interesting text-book which relates to the history of the Three Kingdoms in Chinese history. The Three Kingdoms are the Wei Kingdom, the Chu Kingdom and the Wu Kingdom. It is a history of three territories seeking to survive, each trying to preserve its integrity and sovereignty, how much political guile and strategy and resourcefulness were shown by their generals; but in the end, unfortunately, all three kingdoms disappeared. They were taken over by another power. Although I do not believe in the dictum that history repeats itself, because there are now institutions and devices which prevent history from recurring so often, I will only add that looking around us there are comparable situations in South-East Asia which are like that of the Three Kingdoms in ancient Chinese history.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not my intention to spell out what the Three Kingdoms are in modern South-East Asian history. I will only say, for our edification and education, that we in Singapore should try to read a little more of The Three Kingdoms and make sure that we are not one of the victims of absorption and conquest as the Three Kingdoms were. That is why we thought it extraordinarily important that Singapore should be a member of the United Nations Organisation. There was no such world body in the days of the Three Kingdoms. So when one territory was attacked by another territory, there was no recourse to an appeal or recourse to succour by a world body. But it is fortunate for many small countries today that there is such a body as the Security Council of the United Nations where a considerable amount of dirty linen can be washed in front of the world You have perhaps, to some extent, quite satisfactory measures which can he applied by the world body in the solution of disputes between smaller powers. does not happen, because I believe that, like the able leaders and generals of one of the Three Kingdoms, people in Singapore will also have the resourcefulness to ensure their own survival.

So what he did was he had dummies made of straw, put them on board some barges and sailed the barges down the river. The enemy thought Chu Ker Liang's army was attacking them. (Government Assistance)


    2. "Mr Poh Ber Liak To ask the Minister for Education whether the Government intends to give any assistance to Peng Ghee High School for development, and if he will give details."

    Pursuant to Standing Order No. 20 (2), the Minister for Education supplied the following answer:-

    2. "The answer depends on whether the School Management can fulfil the requirements as laid down in the Government Grant-in-Aid Regulations 1957, with which all schools are expected to comply. For example, the school must, among other things, hold a legal title to the land and have the amount of its own contribution in hand. If the School is in a position to comply with the Regulations. I see no reason why its application for capital grant for building cannot be considered together with others.

Column: 378



    As a matter of fact, Pin Ghee High School is more a Primary than a Secondary school. In 1957 it began with one Secondary I class; by 1964, it had only 6 Secondary classes. The academic standard achieved has been appalling: in 1964, out of 36 candidates who sat for the Government Secondary IV Examination, only 6 passed, of whom 5 passed with Grade III and 1 with Grade I certificate. Since 1957, when this school began its first Secondary I class, it has been encouraged to improve its school buildings and equipment. The Government approved in 1962 capital grants amounting to $5,241 for the school to purchase science equipment and furniture in order to help the school develop gradually its secondary classes into a proper secondary school. But unfortunately, the Management Committee of the school not only had not been able to make any improvements, but also allowed the school administration and discipline to deteriorate. For instance, the school, under its former Management, was known to have sold textbooks at list price, thus making a profit of some $9,000 a year from students, and yet it owed several bookshops a total of $18,000 in September 1964. No serious attempts had ever been made to improve the school buildings, which still consist of 7 blocks of wooden structures with asbestos and attap roofing. Repeated requests by the health authorities to improve its health requirements had not been fully complied with. Only one wooden plank room is available for an all-purpose laboratory; Chemistry, Physics and Biology experiments are all conducted in it. The secondary department of the school is notorious for indiscipline. In November 1964, a pupil was caught intimidating other pupils to subscribe to Barisan Sosialis Party Fund. More recently, school monitors, two of whom were known to have attended meetings organised by the Barisan Sosialis for its cadres, defied the authority of the principal and engaged in producing and

Column: 379

distributing illegal handbills giving a distorted picture of Government policy towards Chinese education.

    Unless the School Management Committee can work selflessly and genuinely for the future well-being of the school, I do not see how all the present indiscipline, poor management and political manipulation by the Barisan Sosialis are going to help develop this school.

    Work has already begun on the construction of a secondary school at 10 m.s. Changi Road at a cost of $1.1 million plus an additional $250,000 for furniture and equipment. This school will be completed next year in time for the enrolment of students in 1967. It will cater for students living in the Kampong Chai Chi, Changi, Tampines, Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong areas who now have to travel long distances to attend school. Before the completion of this school, if parents living in the village nearby Pin Ghee School find it inconvenient to send their children to attend secondary schools elsewhere next year, the Government is quite prepared to open secondary classes at Changkat Primary School situated at 10 m.s. Changi Road to eater for this need until the new secondary school is ready."
